descriptionSet.description: A used Indian postcard with a printed illustration depicting the birth of Shakuntala: Menaka is holding her daughter Shakuntala, while Vishwamitra turns away from them. The illustration by an artist Mudrale is a simple reproduction of a painting by Raja Ravi Varma. The card with a handwritten message was sent to an address in Chirawa, Rajasthan, in 1905. It beares a grey three pies India Postage stamp depicting King Edward VII. On the stamp a postmark indicates the postcard was sent from ??? (illegible) on May 17. Another postmark indicates delivery at Chiwara on May 18, 1905

inscription.text: नवीन आढत हमारी आढतसे सब प्रकारका देशी व विलायती माल किफायत से भेजा जाता है.
Delhiwala Lala Bhishandayal Dharamdas, Attarwala, Jumma Musjid, No. 3553, Ahmedabad
दिल्लीवाला लाला बिशनदयाल धर्मदास अत्तरवाला, जुमामशिद, नम्बर ३ ५ ५ ३, अमदाबाद.

text-??

description-en: A used Indian postcard with a printed illustration depicting the birth of Shakuntala: Menaka is holding her daughter Shakuntala, while Vishwamitra turns away from them. The illustration by an artist Mudrale is a simple reproduction of a painting by Raja Ravi Varma. The card with a handwritten message was sent to an address in Chirawa, Rajasthan, in 1905. It beares a grey three pies India Postage stamp depicting King Edward VII. On the stamp a postmark indicates the postcard was sent from ??? (illegible) on May 17. Another postmark indicates delivery at Chiwara on May 18, 1905 (gs/ma)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Some illustrated postcards were definitely produced for use by Indians. The Priya Paul collection has a few postcards (using coloured card paper) with Indian or Hindu iconography, postmarked around 1904, and printed by companies in Bombay and Calcutta. Many feature a block-print illustration only on the left-half of the address side, leaving the reverse side blank for the message. (Yousuf Saeed)(gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The blank side is usually choked with text, often in cursive Devanagri or Gujarati, the small image simply having religious importance. Does it mean that most Indians were keen to use a postcard primarily for writing a letter, its illustration being secondary, unlike many European users for whom the purpose of sending a picture postcard was to showcase or cherish the image of the location? Almost no Indian user refers to the accompanied image in his/her letter, whereas many European postcard senders make it a point to describe what image they are sending, often hoping the postcard would be a valuable addition to the addressee’s collection. But it is possible that for Indian users the local images or Hindu iconography on postcards were of little significance, and the new images of or from Europe might have excited them more. Hence, in the case of some early Eid cards, the use of visuals takes us into a completely unexpected domain of image translocation. (Yousuf Saeed)(gs)

related literature: Mathur, Saloni, "Wanted Native Views: Collecting colonial postcards of India," in Antionette Burton (ed.) Gender, Sexuality and Colonial Modernities, New York: Routledge, 1999, 95-115. (gs)
related literature: Patterson, Steven, Postcards from the Raj, Patterns of Prejudice, Volume 40, Number 2, Routledge, May 2006, 142-158; see also Saloni Mathur, 1999. (gs)

related hyperlinks: http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/117/index_1.html, last accessed 2011-04-04, online essay "Eid Mubarak: Cross-cultural Image Exchange in Muslim South Asia." by Y. Saeed. (gs)

related literature: Wehbe, Rana, Seeing Beirut through Colonial Postcards: A Charged Reality, [2004]. American University of Beirut, Lebanon, cf. http://webfea.fea.aub.edu.lb/proceedings/2004/SRC-ArD-01.pdf (gs)
related hyperlinks: http://webfea.fea.aub.edu.lb/proceedings/2004/SRC-ArD-01.pdf, last accessed 2012-03-18, article "Seeing Beirut through Colonial Postcards: A Charged Reality" by R. Wehbe. (gs)
